div.em: Current conditions as of 19 Apr 22:56 pm CDT

div.span: A 40 percent chance of showers. Mostly cloudy, with a low around 38. East wind around 5 mph becoming calm. New precipitation amounts of less than a tenth of an inch possible.

A 10 percent chance of showers before 7am. Partly sunny, then gradually becoming sunny, with a high near 66. Breezy, with a west southwest wind 5 to 10 mph becoming west northwest 19 to 24 mph in the afternoon. Winds could gust as high as 36 mph.
Mostly clear, with a low around 35. Breezy, with a northwest wind 15 to 20 mph decreasing to 5 to 10 mph after midnight. Winds could gust as high as 28 mph.

span.span: Tech Tips
This WOOT is for all of our hard working staff, parents, and community!!
Shout Outs:
Mrs. Settje’s Junior High music students
from both Clarkson and Leigh made “Musical Me” digital presentations
using

posters, videos, and power points which told about their musical likes and feelings. They musically shared about awesome songs, quotes, and singers that described them, their personalities, feelings about music, and their current thoughts on this Covid 19 situation. What a great idea!!
Mrs. Sayers’s Entrepreneurship class

recorded their own Shark Tank Pitch in iMovie. We had been working on a box subscription project 1x/week throughout the semester so they recorded themselves selling their product. They did an awesome job!
Mrs. Sayers’s Intro to Business kids
were learning about expanding businesses into new markets. They picked their favorite brand and made an iMovie about a new market they could emerge into.
Zooming with students:
1st grade
had a bedtime story with Mrs. Bruhn and their stuffed animal & blanket.
5th grade
went on a home scavenger hunt.
4th graders
did a Pick 3 Objects challenge. Keep up the great work with keeping our students connected. Their smiles are priceless!! I love seeing the cameos by Mrs. Hillen & Mrs. Settje!
Tech Tips
AR with the Merge Cube:
https://docs.wixstatic.com/ugd/879cdc_2146ac3eac0045dcb440d715042de3bd.pdf
: Have students cut out the Merge Cube, create and then download apps to experience a concept in 3D. Merge Cube Activity Plans:
https://mergeedu.com/edu-resources/activity-plans
List of
Merge Cube Apps

: This link will take you to a Google Search-Click on the first Purple Link to find the list of Merge Cube links. ****I have used the paper Merge Cube before in class and it works just like a real Merge Cube. Kids can download the apps on Kindles, iPads, phones.
https://insertlearning.com/
: Insert instructional content on any webpage
https://artsandculture.google.com/
: Google Arts and Culture
http://www.viewpure.com/
: Watch Youtube in a pure way.
https://www.commonlit.org/
: Relevant reading for students across curriculums. Grades 5-12. Great for nonfiction reading, comparing texts, etc.
https://www.pbs.org/kenburns/
: Ken Burns Documentaries

span.span: Leigh Community Schools Mission Statement

The mission of Leigh Community Schools is to foster a positive educational culture where: STUDENTS thrive, TEACHERS guide, ADMINISTRATORS lead, PARENTS support and the COMMUNITY is the foundation for all. WE ARE LEIGH!
L
earning
E
mpowers
I
ndividuals to
G
reat
H
eights
Leigh Community Schools Students, Families and Community,

On April 1st, the Governor issued a statewide Directed Health Measure directing schools across Nebraska to not return to a normal status in the current school year. Instead, schools should continue to operate the remainder of the year without students in the building. The Governor also mandated no extracurricular activities through May 31st. We know this is a very sad and challenging time for our whole school staff, students, parents, and community members. We will be in contact with our Seniors on how graduation may be able to look this year. We are very proud of our Seniors and want to celebrate their great accomplishments.

We will continue with our lunch program. If you would like lunches for your school-age children, you may call the elementary office at 487-3301 by 9:00 a.m. Monday - Friday. You may pick up lunches at the elementary from 11:00-12:00 or if needed, we can deliver the lunches. NO lunches will be available on April 10th or 13th as this is our scheduled break.
We will continue with our alternate learning until May 20th. When necessary, we will be making adjustments to the process to better serve our students.
Our Preschool - 6th-grade plan for continuity of learning includes:

Preschool will provide weekly enrichment packets. Kindergarten through 6th grade will continue enrichment packets and begin instructional packets at a later date. Packets may be picked up each Monday between 7:45 am-12:00 pm. Packets not picked up will be delivered later in the week. **Please note due to scheduled break, April 13th packets will be available for pick up on Tuesday, April 14th.**

The expectation for the packet is to be completed and returned to the elementary by the following Monday. A drop off box is available outside of the elementary building. The teachers will review materials, make comments and use a pass/no harm system for any grading.
At the elementary, Zoom will be used as a communication tool and not an instructional tool. Teachers will set up a zoom once a week for their class.
Our 7-12 grade plan for continuity of learning includes:

At the 7-12 level, we are utilizing remote learning. All students have either a Chromebook or Macbook computer. The teachers will post weekly learning objectives and assignments on Canvas or Google classroom. Those students without Internet access receive paper copies placed into packets. The packets are distributed every Monday.

During the school closure, grading is established as pass/no harm. If a student demonstrates proficiency on an assignment, this is noted in the grade book. If an assignment is not submitted or fails to reach a level of basic proficiency, no grade is entered into the grade book. College credit courses and high school online courses will continue to be graded as they were prior to the closure.

For grades 9-12, completion of assigned work during the fourth quarter is tied to earning academic credit for the second semester. Students earning a mid-term passing grade as of March 18 and successfully completing work during the school closure, will be awarded full credit for the second semester.

Each 9-12 grade teacher will have virtual office hours, via Zoom meetings, every day that school is in session. At this time, students may communicate face-to-face with their teacher. In addition, some teachers will establish Zoom meetings once a week for specific courses.
All teachers will be available 7:50-3:50 Monday - Friday for assistance. Teachers may be reached by email, cell phone if available or you may call the school office and leave a message.
As we continue with our new normal of constant change, please feel free to call us with any questions or concerns. Thank you for all of your support as we move through this process.
Sincerely,
Troy Holmberg
7-12 Principal/AD
tholmberg@leigh.esu7.org
Stephanie Petersen
Elementary Principal/Superintendent
spetersen@leigh.esu7.org

a.aria-label: Read more about COVID-19 Leigh Community Schools Update - 4/3/20

h3.a: Leigh JR/SR High: Zoom Office Hours

span.span: LEIGH JR/SR HIGH: ZOOM OFFICE HOURS

Through the remainder of the school year, all Leigh Jr/Sr teachers will have virtual office hours throughout the school week via Zoom meetings. Teachers are sharing their meeting codes with the students. The Zoom meetings give our teachers and students the opportunity to interact face-to-face during our building closure. Each teacher has one hour set aside each day school is in session. Times are listed below. Individual teachers will also have additional Zoom meetings for specific courses at other times during the week.
We encourage students to utilize the office hour time to ask questions and share thoughts. We know it is not the same as being in the classroom together, but it does get us closer to that atmosphere.
If you have any questions regarding the remote learning program, including Zoom, contact Mr. Holmberg at the high school (402-487-2228) or by email (tholmberg@leigh.esu7.org)

span.span: Whether you are heading to the mountains to go skiing, travelling to another country, or even just going to the lake to go boating, vacations are meant to give your brain a chance to escape. They are meant for people to forget about the same, dull, everyday tasks and enjoy time away. I believe that is true.

Mental breaks are usually a day break to rejuvenate your brain and let you relax—one day dedicated to enjoyment, which people sometimes don’t get. A day break can give your brain a quick break, and you don’t have to worry about doing any of your daily tasks. Some people might not believe what a difference a day to relax can make.

Although day breaks are satisfactory, vacations are even greater stress relievers. Everyone has a lot on their plate. Students have homework that they have to get done, as well as extracurriculars, jobs, and many other tasks they have to attend to. Parents have kids to take care of, jobs to report to, and many other priorities that they are expected to check off their To-Do list each day.

In my opinion, everyone needs time away from all of their priorities to just relax, get rest, and enjoy some time away. The answer to relaxing and having fun is a vacation. Everybody needs a couple of days to help clear their minds and rejuvenate their bodies. It serves as more than a mental break if you have multiple days where you don’t have to worry about fulfilling usual responsibilities.

I feel that vacations are very necessary. Repeating the same routine everyday, like going to work, school, or whatever you do during the week can get very boring. Vacations are helpful to many people who have busy lives, instead of just a short mental break. Taking a longer break can be refreshing, and stem the monotony that people are used to.
Vacations are truly what you make them. You can choose to make it boring like the rest of your days, or you can choose to enjoy them and let them help you relax, refresh, and rejuvenate yourself!

In light of recent coronavirus headlines inciting national fear, vacations and breaks are not able to be taken during this time even though they are so important. We are being quarantined in our homes, and not able to be around our friends, community members, or even some family members. Some may say they are on an extended “vacation.” They are at home and unable to leave their homes. Some are struggling with this “vacation” and miss their friends, family, and maybe even school or jobs. Many are missing out on important events that would have profoundly impacted their lives and created meaningful memories.

As citizens, we don’t know when the end of this pandemic will come, but we hope it is soon. This extended “vacation” may be enjoyable for some, but for others, it’s heartbreaking. Of course, this is something none of us ever expected, but it has ruined so much for so many. But even in our current situation, we cannot forget to make some sort of “break” or “mini vacation” a priority. Even if this might mean going for a walk outside instead of heading to Omaha for an exciting day out. Anything we can do to provide a minute to relax will provide clarity and rejuvenation in a time when we need it most!

In all, even though some people think that vacations are a waste of time and productivity, I really believe they can benefit everyone. I am a strong believer that vacations are great, and you should make the most of them!

a.aria-label: Read more about Why Vacations Are So Important

span.span: August 22, 2001, was a day of pure joy for Chad and Kristi Settje as they welcomed their first child, Reagan Settje, into the world in Broken Bow, Nebraska.

Reagan is part of a large family. She has four younger sisters: Kennedy, age 16, twins Brynn and Baylee, age 12, and Bergan, age 8. To round out the family is a tiny dog, Jax. Reagan’s grandparents are Gary and Judy Blessen of Creston, Mike and Cindy Settje of Leigh, and Tom and Sue Kabes of Clarkson.

To get to know this senior a little bit better, Reagan says the three words to describe her best are “responsible, competitive, and a perfectionist.” Her worst bad habit is chewing her cheeks and her biggest pet peeve is when people chew loud.
Reagan has many favorites. Her favorite subjects in school are child development, parenting, or any FCS class. Her favorite TV show is
Grey’s Anatomy
, her favorite food is stroganoff, her favorite song is “Just the Way” by Parmalee, and her favorite sports team is the Nebraska Cornhuskers.
Outside of school you can find Reagan babysitting or swimming when the weather is nice.

Throughout high school Reagan has been involved in FCCLA for six years; volleyball, basketball, journalism, band, and One-Act for four years; yearbook, National Honor Society, Quiz Bowl, and Youth Advisory Committee for three years; and FBLA, dance, and track for two years.

Reagan has received honors in many activities. She served as FCCLA President, received Student of the Month several times, earned Academic All-State honors in Volleyball and One-Act, received an Outstanding Actress Award in One-Act, and has been a FCCLA State STAR qualifier.
With her many accomplishments, Reagan says her proudest high school moment was making it to State One-Act three years in a row.
Reagan says her most embarrassing moment of her high school career is falling down the stairs at One-Act practice and rolling her ankle.
After graduation, Reagan plans to attend Wayne State College and major in Elementary Education.

Three goals on Reagan’s bucket list are to travel, start a family, and go bungee jumping. If she could travel anywhere in the world, she would go to St. Lucia because she says “it looks really pretty, it’s warm, and there’s a beach.”
In 10-15 years, Reagan sees herself married, working as a teacher, and having kids. If she is fortunate enough to win the lottery, she would buy a house, pay off student loans, and travel the world.
Reagan’s advice to underclassmen is, “Focus on what is happening right now. Enjoy the moment and don’t procrastinate.”
Congratulations and good luck, Reagan!

a.aria-label: Read more about Senior Spotlight: Reagan Settje

If you need to pick up your child’s belongings, both buildings will be open this Thursday and Friday from 8:00-9:00 a.m.
